meanings.definition: To perform or speak without preparation
meanings.sent1: During the talent show, Sarah had to extemporise a dance routine when the music suddenly stopped.
meanings.sent2: The comedian had to extemporise a joke when the audience unexpectedly shouted out a suggestion.
meanings.sent3: In the play, the actor had to extemporise a line when his co-star forgot their cue.
meanings.sent4: The chef had to extemporise a new dish when they ran out of a key ingredient.
meanings.sent5: The teacher had to extemporise a lesson plan when the projector broke down.

meanings.definition: To improvise or make up on the spot
meanings.sent1: At the party, Tom had to extemporise a toast when he realized he forgot his notes.
meanings.sent2: The street performer would often extemporise songs based on the people passing by.
meanings.sent3: During the game, the player had to extemporise a strategy to win against a tough opponent.
meanings.sent4: The artist would extemporise new designs when inspiration struck unexpectedly.
meanings.sent5: The explorer had to extemporise a shelter using whatever materials were available in the wilderness.
